item.title: FDA approves lenacapavir for HIV treatment; Science journal hails it as 'breakthrough of the year' - The New Indian Express
item.description:
FDA Approves Lenacapavir for HIV Treatment; Science Journal Hails it as 'Breakthrough of the Year'

Publication Date: 30 Dec 2024
Source: AP

The FDA has approved Lenacapavir, an injectable drug that protects against HIV for six months with each dose, which has been recognized by Science journal as a major breakthrough in combating the HIV/AIDS crisis.

  • Lenacapavir provides long-term protection against HIV with biannual injections.
  • Science journal labeled it 'breakthrough of the year' for its efficacy in HIV prevention.
  • Clinical trials showed 100% efficacy among African adolescent girls and 99.9% among gender-diverse populations.
  • HOPE for reducing global HIV infections relies on access and demand for the drug.
"It has the potential if we can do it right, which means going big and getting it out there." - Linda-Gail Bekker, University of Cape Town

Lenacapavir represents a significant advancement in HIV prevention, with the potential to transform public health efforts against the epidemic.

item.title: Sick kids and cold season blues: Ultimate guide for parents to prevent dehydration in children - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Boosting Kids' Immunity: A Parent's Guide to Preventing Dehydration During Illness

Date & Source: Published on HT Lifestyle

Introduction: Seasonal changes often bring fluctuating weather conditions and an increased risk of illnesses in children, which can lead to dehydration and reduced energy levels.

  1. Dehydration and its impact on immunity: Pediatric expert Dr. NL Sridhar explains that dehydration can weaken children's immunity and leave them more vulnerable to infections.
  2. How seasonal illnesses lead to dehydration: Fever, nausea, and vomiting are common in children during seasonal changes and can result in fluid, electrolyte, and energy deficits.
  3. Highlighting the role of fluid, electrolyte, and energy (FEE) deficits in supporting recovery: Dr. NL Sridhar emphasizes the importance of replenishing fluids, electrolytes, and energy to counteract the effects of dehydration.
  4. The Role of Electrolytes in Recovery: Electrolytes like sodium, potassium, and magnesium are vital for recovery during seasonal illnesses.
  5. The Importance of Timely Intervention: Early identification and management of dehydration and energy deficits can significantly improve recovery in children.
Notable Quote: "Ready-to-drink formulations with a scientifically balanced composition of electrolytes and energy are particularly beneficial as they ensure consistent quality and taste." - Dr. NL Sridhar

Conclusion: Parents should remain vigilant for signs of dehydration and consult pediatricians for appropriate care, prioritizing hydration and addressing energy needs to help children navigate seasonal transitions with resilience and good health.

Disclaimer: The information provided in this article are scientific facts only and not a substitute for any professional advice. Please consult a doctor / nutritionist for more information on managing dehydration during infections.

item.title: Your dog could have diabetes. Yes, you read that right - India Today
item.description:
Your Dog Could Have Diabetes: A Common Yet Often Unnoticed Condition

Published on Dec 31, 2023 - Source: India Today

Diabetes in pets, especially dogs and cats, is more common than many pet owners realize. While it's not as prevalent as in humans, it's a serious condition that requires proper management. Sadly, around 20% of pets with diabetes are euthanized within a year of diagnosis due to various factors, including lack of awareness and understanding of the condition.

  1. Glucose is the body's main energy source, regulated by insulin, a hormone produced by the pancreas.
  2. In diabetic animals, low insulin levels cause high blood sugar. Middle-aged, obese, and unspayed female dogs are at higher risk.
  3. There are two types of diabetes in pets: Type 1, which is common in dogs but rare in cats, and Type 2, which is the opposite.
  4. Symptoms of diabetes in pets develop gradually but can worsen quickly if untreated. Key signs include increased thirst, urination, appetite, and weight loss.
  5. Cats may develop a flat-footed stance, while dogs are prone to cataracts.
  6. Management of diabetes in pets involves SGLT2 inhibitors for early stages and long-acting insulin injections for advanced cases, along with gradual weight loss and low-carb diets for cats.
  7. Insulin therapy remains the cornerstone of treatment, despite the rarity of diabetes reversal in dogs.
"Sadly, around 20% of pets with diabetes are euthanized within a year of diagnosis."

Understanding and managing diabetes in pets is crucial for their well-being and longevity. Regular vet check-ups and proper diet management can significantly improve the quality of life for diabetic pets.

item.title: Each cigarette smoked steals 20 mins of life expectancy: UCL study - Business Standard
item.description:
Each Cigarette Smoked Steals 20 Minutes of Life Expectancy, Reveals UCL Study

Date: October 2023 | Source: University College London

A new research from University College London indicates that each cigarette smoked reduces life expectancy by an average of 20 minutes. The study also found that quitting smoking can significantly recover lost life.

  • Every pack of 20 cigarettes smoked correlates with a loss of nearly seven hours of life.
  • Quitting smoking on New Year’s Day can reclaim an entire day of life by January 8.
  • By mid-February, individuals could recover one full week; by year-end, up to 50 days.
  • The UK government is implementing measures to phase out the sale of tobacco to individuals born after January 1, 2009.
  • A survey indicates that 53% of smokers plan to quit as part of their 2025 New Year resolutions.
  • Smoking is responsible for around 80,000 deaths annually in the UK.
“Stopping smoking is one of the best things you can do to improve your current and future health.” - Jeanelle de Gruchy, England’s Deputy Chief Medical Officer

Quitting smoking greatly improves health almost immediately, with benefits such as easier breathing and increased energy levels observed within 72 hours.

item.title: IIT Bombay researchers develop needle-free ‘shock’ syringe - News9 LIVE
item.description:
IIT Bombay researchers develop needle-free ‘shock’ syringe

New Delhi: Researchers from IIT Bombay have developed a ‘shock’ syringe that delivers medication using shock waves, eliminating the need for needles.

The device uses a micro shock tube to create a rapid jet stream of liquid that penetrates the skin, allowing for painless drug delivery.

  • The shock syringe is longer than a regular ballpoint pen and uses pressurized nitrogen to deliver medication.
  • Tests on lab rats showed results comparable to conventional syringes.
  • Could facilitate quicker vaccination drives and alleviate fears associated with needles, especially for children.
  • Less skin damage compared to traditional needle injections, reducing trauma from injections.
“The shock syringe is designed to deliver the medication rapidly,” - Priyanka Hankare, lead author of the research paper.

This innovation highlights the potential to transform drug delivery methods, pending further research and regulatory approval.

item.title: Drinking coffee every day could have a big impact on your body, according to a new study - Marca.com
item.description:
Daily Coffee Consumption Linked to Major Health Benefits

Published on Dec 30, 2024 in Marca

Consuming a cup of coffee daily can have significant health impacts, according to a new study.

  1. Cardiovascular benefits: Moderate coffee consumption reduces the risk of cardiovascular disease due to antioxidants like polyphenols that improve heart health and blood flow.
  2. Cognitive performance improvement: Coffee's caffeine can enhance alertness, concentration, and lower the risk of cognitive decline with age.
  3. Reducing chronic diseases risk: Daily coffee consumption is linked to a lower risk of type 2 diabetes and certain cancers due to its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.

item.title: Burnt your mouth? 5 home remedies to heal faster - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Home Remedies to Soothe a Burnt Mouth

Published: December 29, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

Burnt your mouth on hot food or drinks? Here are some quick and effective home remedies to heal your mouth burn and reduce pain.

  1. Cold water or ice cubes: Rinse your mouth with cold water or suck on ice cubes to reduce swelling and numb the pain immediately.
  2. Dairy relief with yogurt or milk: Milk or yogurt cools the burning sensation and creates a protective layer to soothe irritation.
  3. Honey's healing power: Honey, with its anti-inflammatory properties, helps reduce pain, prevent infection, and promotes faster healing.
  4. Aloe vera gel for quick relief: Aloe vera’s cooling properties reduce inflammation and speed up healing when applied directly to the burn.
  5. Saltwater rinse: A simple saltwater rinse cleanses the area and reduces the risk of infection. Rinse several times a day.

Try these home remedies to find quick relief and speed up the healing process.

item.title: 5 ways to healthy bones for a smooth winter pregnancy - India Today
item.description:
5 Ways to Ensure Healthy Bones During Winter Pregnancy

Published On: Dec 30, 2024

Published By: Shyam Balasubramanian

Strong bones are essential for both the expectant mother and the developing baby, ensuring adequate calcium supply and a sturdy skeletal framework. Here are five ways to optimize bone health for winter pregnancy.

  • Calcium-rich foods: Include dairy products, leafy greens, and fortified foods to meet the 1,000 mg calcium requirement during pregnancy.
  • Vitamin D: Aim for sunlight exposure and include fortified foods to aid calcium absorption.
  • Low-impact, weight-bearing exercises: Engage in gentle activities like walking or swimming to maintain bone density.
  • Hydration: Stay hydrated with water and herbal tea to support joint health and bone strength.
  • Balanced diet: Prioritize magnesium and Vitamin K, and avoid smoking while limiting alcohol and caffeine intake.
Dr Asha Dalal, director at Sir H.N. Reliance Foundation Hospital, emphasizes the importance of a well-rounded nutritional strategy for bone health during pregnancy.

Maintaining strong bones during pregnancy is crucial, especially in winter, to support both mother and child’s health.

item.title: Problem Peeing? 6 Things All Men Should Know About Enlarged Prostate - TheHealthSite
item.description:
Problem Peeing? 6 Things All Men Should Know About Enlarged Prostate

Publication Date: Not specified Source: The Health Site

After the age of 40, men should be vigilant about their health, especially regarding urinary issues that could indicate an enlarged prostate, a common condition requiring medical attention.

  • Prostate enlargement can result in various urinary symptoms.
  • Symptoms include poor urine stream, interrupted flow, and frequent urination.
  • Diagnosis typically involves physical exams, blood tests, and PSA tests.
  • Treatment options range from medications to surgery.
  • Lifestyle changes, such as diet and exercise, can help manage symptoms.
  • Immediate medical attention is required for severe or sudden symptoms.
"One should not hesitate to consult a urologist if he is experiencing symptoms of an enlarged prostate. Early diagnosis and treatment can significantly improve quality of life." - Dr. Amit Saple

It is crucial for men over 40 to remain proactive about prostate health to prevent complications, including the potential for prostate cancer.

item.title: Pune’s first robotic-assisted hip replacement improves recovery and mobility for patients - Healthcare Radius
item.description:
Pune's First Robotic-Assisted Hip Replacement Surgery

Date: November 27, 2024
Source: Healthcare Radius

Pune's first robotic-assisted hip replacement surgery, using the direct anterior approach, was successfully completed at Sahyadri Hospitals. A 65-year-old patient diagnosed with hip avascular necrosis (AVN) underwent the procedure and was discharged with excellent post-operative progress.

  • The robotic system combined with the direct anterior approach provided unparalleled precision and safety.
  • Patients experienced reduced pain, quicker recovery, and more natural movement post-surgery.
  • Immediate postoperative mobility significantly improved the quality of life for patients with AVN hip.
  • The robotic system enabled customized surgery plans tailored to each patient's specific anatomy.
Dr. Abhijit Agashe said, “This method has not only enhanced functional outcomes but has also allowed immediate postoperative mobility, significantly improving the quality of life for patients with AVN Hip.”

This breakthrough in orthopedic surgery sets a new standard in the field, particularly beneficial for those suffering from hip problems.

item.title: Winter stroke alert: Why cold weather spikes your risk of a brain attack, prevention tips - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Winter stroke crisis: How to spot, treat and prevent the silent killer i.e. brain attack in cold weather.

Date: Dec 30, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

As winter brings colder temperatures, the risk of strokes increases due to various physiological and behavioral factors, including dehydration and inactivity. Dr. Neeraj Singh shares critical insights on identifying stroke symptoms and the importance of timely treatment.

  • Cold weather can increase blood pressure as blood vessels constrict to conserve heat.
  • Dehydration caused by reduced water intake raises blood viscosity, increasing stroke risk.
  • Symptoms of a stroke follow the BEFAST acronym: Balance, Eyes, Face Drooping, Arm Weakness, Speech Difficulty, and Time.
  • Immediate response is crucial to prevent lasting damage and complications.
  • Preventive measures include monitoring blood pressure, staying hydrated, and managing diet and exercise.
“The increased prevalence of strokes during winter can be because of physiological, environmental and behavioural factors.” - Dr. Neeraj Singh

Overall, it is vital to take proactive steps during winter to mitigate the risk of strokes and ensure a prompt response to symptoms.

item.title: Study of matrix modifications by nano-clay on the mechanical properties of AA3003 honeycomb sandwich panels - Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham
item.description:
Boosting AA3003 Honeycomb Sandwich Panels' Strength with Nano-Clay

Date & Source: Published in 2022 in the Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science.

Introduction: Researchers from Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham explored the use of nano-clay to enhance the mechanical properties of AA3003 aluminum honeycomb sandwich panels.

  • Face/core debonding, a common issue, was addressed by adding nano-clay to the composite at varying concentrations (0%, 2%, 4%, and 6%).
  • The study found significant improvements in mechanical characteristics at nano-clay concentrations between 2% and 4%.
  • In-plane compression and flexural failure loads increased by 45% and 81%, respectively, compared to a pristine sample.
  • Higher strain rates led to increased failure loads.
  • Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images showed better adhesion between the aluminum honeycomb core and face sheets.

Conclusion: The addition of nano-clay, particularly at concentrations between 2% and 4%, can substantially enhance the mechanical properties of AA3003 honeycomb sandwich panels.

item.title: Single cigarette cuts 20 minutes from life expectancy, study reveals - WION
item.description:
Single Cigarette Cuts 20 Minutes from Life Expectancy, Study Reveals

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: The Guardian

A recent study conducted by University College London has highlighted the devastating effects of cigarette smoking, revealing that a single cigarette can reduce life expectancy by approximately 20 minutes. With an average pack of 20 cigarettes potentially cutting nearly seven hours off a smoker's life.

  • The study combines data from the British Doctors Study and the Million Women Study.
  • Smoking contributes to around 80,000 deaths annually in the UK.
  • The research emphasizes that smoking is the leading preventable cause of death and disease.
  • Supports available for smokers include the NHS Quit Smoking app and personalized plans.
“Every cigarette smoked costs precious minutes of life.” - Prof. Sanjay Agrawal

This research serves as a powerful reminder of the urgent need to address cigarette smoking, which has significant implications for health and the economy.

item.title: Study links social inequality to dementia-related changes in brain - Deccan Herald
item.description:
Study Links Social Inequality to Dementia-Related Changes in Brain

Published: 30 December 2024, 08:54 IST

Social inequality is directly linked to changes in brain structure that are associated with ageing and dementia, according to a recent study involving over 2,100 participants from Latin America and the US.

  • The study found that socioeconomic disparities are related to brain volume and connectivity changes, especially in memory-related regions.
  • Greater structural inequality correlated with reduced brain health, with pronounced effects observed in Latin America.
  • Latinos with Alzheimer's experienced the most severe impacts, highlighting how societal inequality may exacerbate neurodegeneration.
  • The findings call for interventions targeting socioeconomic factors to improve brain health.
"Our findings emphasise the urgency of integrating not only individual social determinants of health into global brain health research but also macro-level exposome factors such as social and physical variables." - Agustina Legaz, Latin American Brain Health Institute

This research underscores the critical role of structural inequality in shaping brain health and the necessity for targeted actions to address these disparities in specific regions.

item.title: From smog to stroke: How does air quality affect cardiovascular health? - APN News
item.description:
Air Pollution's Hidden Threat: How it Affects Cardiovascular Health

Date & Source: December 2024, APN News

Introduction: Cardiovascular health is under threat from environmental factors, with air pollution being a significant concern. This article explores how air pollution contributes to heart-related issues, including strokes and heart attacks.

  1. Air pollution, particularly fine particulate matter (PM2.5), triggers inflammation, oxidative stress, and vascular dysfunction.
  2. Long-term exposure to polluted air can lead to atherosclerosis, increasing the risk of heart attacks and strokes.
  3. The elderly, individuals with pre-existing health conditions, and urban residents are most vulnerable.
  4. Air pollution increases the risk of both ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes.
  5. Preventative measures include using air quality apps, air purifiers, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle.
Improving air quality significantly reduces the risk of preventable cardiovascular diseases.

Conclusion: Addressing air pollution is crucial for promoting public health and reducing cardiovascular risks.
